body.p: I thank you for your thoughtfulness in rendering me the Atlantic with your glorious poem which has caught up the grandeur & harmony of the Cretian itself.
I hope you will take the Crusades in hand in reference to Crete & the contest betwixt Christian & Mussalman .

A grand subject worthy of true genius! A gathering of natures as shining & wild as that now tossing about in these States, all bent on driving the Turks & Saracens from Christian land. Popes, Kings, Emperors, he of France the sainte Louis IX & the English monarch Richard Coeur de Lion, Martinus Aussens & princesses, the flower of the nobility, all armed to the teeth, armor-clad with no thought but hatred to the Turk & love for Christ & for Womanhood, which the Turk defiles. Immense Caravanserais slacking from all lands, for several centuries, by rapt men—Peter the Hermit, Walter the Pennyless, all classes joining, all races, all ages; children's crusades; eighty thousand children En route for Holy Land; rabble; loafers; religious & otherwise join; thieves; prostitutes; all; high & low, virtuous & vicious, all humanity on horseback! But mark
but then mere thousands of sailors; the ships of Venice, Genoa & Spain & behold the result! While their ships were crossexamining Mediterranean & Aegean sea to find the best harbour wherein to lay hand on Turk they became acquainted with navigation, with the art of navigatg navigating

The spirit of maritime discovery was thus initiated by these crusading fleets, & when this spirit had culminated in the discovery of America, then Crusading spirit dies out & trading spirit, venturesome, engendering negro-traffic, was ushered into existence.
Hence the poet is right to conclude that the Enterprise which originated in Christian Enthusiasm, was killed by the spirit of maritime discovery to which it had given birth

If the Genoese & Spanish sailors had not been experimenting on the sea in the Crusading expeditions, the best of discovery would not have been developed; Columbus would not have been incited to his expedition & America would not have been discovered.

And then the poetry that was born by the Crusades. Tasso's Gerusalemme Liberata, & Goethe's drama, Torquato Tasso with his poetic love of Princess Eleonora. And the chivalry, the heroic, martial spirit; the martyr; the Christ spirit the millions of Christians slain in the attempt to wrest the sepulchre from Turk.

You see the connection. The discovery of America had the excellent
result of the Crusading expeditions. But the spirit of Enterprise crushed that of religious entusiasm & thus it was that the Turk was allowed to remain to oppress Crete & Greece & now America repays the debt which it owes to the poor Christians of the East whose dream was sealed because America had to be discovered & a maelstrom of material Enterprise to be let loose
How grandly you might weave all this together in words & mankind-stirring stanzas! Ponder over it & if I can make further suggestions, let me know

postscript.p: I enclose an outline of the main idea in a map.
I further enclose a string of sentences, which express part of the ideas.

Christians remain in bondage to Turks. Damnation!
Ages elapse; suffering; woes; Greek use of independence
American men alive then are to her debt
Revival of moral enthusiasm! Down with the Turk!
America accomplishes the mission of the , interrupted by the event consequent upon her discovery.
postscript.p: Full two hundred years before Columbus came
The way to his advent was clearly traced
By the armadas thronged with Crusaders
Who drove the Moslem Muslim from the land of Christ.
While all Christian men & women too seized the pilgrim's staff
To wrest the hallowed East from Turkish grasp Thrilled only with the Sermon on the Mount
And caring not for tracing hidden empires
It so happened that their wrestlings with the seas opened new vistas to ships & the art of navigation.
Genoa, Venice & Spain were most buoy on that craft
Their swift sailors spread dismay in Moslim Muslim camps
Even as in these days the Syran Syrian Candiot slaves
But mark! this sea alliance of Italy & Spain
Stretches far beyond the Saviour's tomb
Columbus was its immaculate conception and a new world thus linked with old Palistine Palestine
Peter the Hermit & Walter the Penniless little dreamt
That their rhapsodies would give a lift to sailors and wings to the crossâcolonies of the sea
Until the seamen struck upon these shores
To communicate this mystic bond between East & West which the Voge's & Castilian fleets had initiated in olden times
Alas! greed soon followed in the train of enterprise
The crusaders degenerated into traders
The Turk descecrated the tomb of Christ and built his harem in the Holy Virgin's land.
New centuries have since come & gone
But the old bond between East & West survives
When Arcade fell into thousand Christian martyrs & Men & women gave their mete to Crete
Then the old bond revives with all its mystic charm.
Pilgrim Rock & Calvary, Crusaders & Columbus
and all the chivalric, holy trinity of them get revived
To do in mere days & in our quiet way
Which was done of yore in turmoil & confusion
So great is the result of the Genoen's adventure
That our influence transcend all the armies of all the Crusaders
Let us pay the debt we owe to these great souls
Where monarched Europe failed, let free Columbia win.
Let our nation give the honour of fellowship to Crete
To Crete delivered from the Turkish yoke
And by a divine law of grandation
They consummate the work in which Saint Louis was failed.
The enterprise that killed medeival capture built up our Continent
Our bounties shall yet atone for a guilt that brought us into being
The Turk need not complain for he had his spree
And more than this: when he is herded back to Asian wilds
He may then apply what he was by Greek & Cretan Cretian
But he shall no longer rule in Christian lands
His time is up; even Stanley sounds his deathâknell
Let him not stand upon the works of his giving, but go.—
Crete redeemed shall lead the way to Holy Sepulchre
And upon the grave of Him of Nazareth
America feels he stands became
Are Popes, Sultans, Kings the only annointed of the Lord
Or are we so given up to policy & self
And join the sceptic who decried the age
Let the People resolve to oust the Turk
& we, too may have our age of Christian divinity>
